intro: Lippia globiflora f. incana, commonly known as the hairy lippia, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and showy inflorescences. The plant features slender, branched stems covered in fine, white hairs, giving it a distinctive silvery appearance. Its small, tubular flowers are typically blue or violet, arranged in compact clusters at the ends of the branches. The leaves are narrow and often have a slightly rough texture, contributing to its unique botanical identity.
